before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"fum43","text":"Core sub-sampling: required material and working conditions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":59}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ek5oq","text":"-Be in a clean room, ideally positively pressurized ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"128bc","text":"-Wear gloves, disposable blouse and disposable hair cap","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eul5d","text":"-Clean the work space with bleach (3 to 10%) and then with ethanol (70%)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2u0kd","text":"-see Fulton 2012 for more detailed information on working conditions for ancient DNA (aDNA)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eu7ga","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1f3g9","text":"Core sub-sampling: protocol","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"abjjr","text":"Put the metal plates in alcohol to burn them and decontaminate them. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"96ep8","text":"Insert the metal plates into the core to cut the slice. You can remove the sediment slice keeping the pressure on the slice. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"60qd0","text":"Remove the edges (around 3/5 mm of thickness), which were in contact with air and the coring tube. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3a7m4","text":"Cut the sample in two parts","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f8dmp","text":"Put the 2 samples from the heart of the sediment slice in 2 DNA-free falcons of 50 ml (we can start to extract one sub-sample and keep the second as an archive in case we need it later)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"54nh1","text":"Keep open a DNA-free falcon on the laboratory working bench. You will use it as sampling control.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"acec8","text":"Extract directly after sampling or put in a freezer at - 18°C to extract later. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7md2e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cs4ua","text":"Keep the edges of the slices and weight wet and then dry to estimate the water content and then the dry weight of the samples for the DNA analyses. The estimation of the dry weight of the samples used for the DNA analyses will be used to determine the quantity of saturated phosphate buffer to add.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"akmse","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5lu5l","text":"Over the past decade, an increasing number of studies has used environmental DNA from lake sediments to trace past lake ecosystem and landscape changes, agricultural activities or human presence and more broadly the biodiversity. In the environment, DNA can be found as intracellular and extracellular DNA (iDNA and exDNA). The contribution of each of these pools varies according to the environments, but exDNA often represents a high proportion of the total DNA (e.g. Vuillemin et al. 2017 and reference therein). Focusing the analyses on these different pools will lead to different community composition and structure of communities (e.g. Vuillemin et al. 2017). For plants, we propose to focus on the exDNA fraction to avoid the extraction of DNA from plant macro-remains, which might lead to an overrepresentation of these taxa and limit the detection of the other, “rarer” taxa. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eb84m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9d4um","text":"The manipulation of ancient DNA is delicate, and the biases brought during the experiments can be multiple. Therefore, it is essential to work carefully, under strict laboratory conditions, with multiple controls and several replicates of samples or extraction or PCR (e.g. Fulton 2012).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dl818","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"egp6e","text":"This protocol details a sampling and extraction method of exDNA from sediments. This method was firstly developed for soils by Taberlet et al. 2012. It uses a phosphate buffer to desorb the DNA fragments from particles such as clays and then, the binding, wash and elution buffers from the NucleoSpin® Soil kit (Macherey-Nagel). Here we present a modified protocol from Taberlet et al. 2012. One modification consists in the addition of a concentration step (by using the amicon ultra centrigugal filter system) after the mixing of sediments with the saturated phosphate buffer. This step allow to increase the DNA yield. The quantity of phosphate buffer is usually based on the quantity of wet sediments (e.g. for 15g of wet sediment/soil, we add 15 ml of phosphate buffer). However, because lake sediments can have very different water content (depending on the composition and compaction) and because the exDNA is adsorbed onto particles, we now propose to base the phosphate buffer quantity on the dry weight of sediments. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2m656","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"24vfm","text":"    Fulton T., 2012. Setting Up an Ancient DNA Laboratory. Book Chapter, Ancient DNA in Methods in Molecular Biology edited by Shapiro B. and Hofreiter M., 1-11. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7e8u1","text":"    Taberlet, P., Prud’Homme, S.M., Campione, E., Roy, J., Miquel, C., Shehzad, W., Gielly, L., Rioux, D., Choler, P., Clément, J.‐C., Melodelima, C., Pompanon, F. and Coissac, E, 2012. Soil sampling and isolation of extracellular DNA from large amount of starting material suitable for metabarcoding studies. Molecular Ecology, 21: 1816-1820.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ec4vb","text":"    Vuillemin A., Horn F., Alawi M., Henny C., Wagner D., Crowe S. A., Kallmeyer J., 2017. Preservation and Significance of Extracellular DNA in Ferruginous Sediments from Lake Towuti, Indonesia. Frontiers in Microbiology 8, 1440.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a47sn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"ebims","text":"All steps must be carried out in a sterile laboratory with sterile equipment as well. Experimenters must equip themselves accordingly (disposable blouse, gloves, mask, disposable hair cap) in order to reduce all possible ways of contamination.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6pnmf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dasin","text":" status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"bk2s","text":"Preparation of the SW2 buffer within the kit (NucleoSpin® Soil kit from Macherey-Nagel):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dcvbo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6546v","text":"This step is only FOR the FIRST USE of this BUFFER","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bpubu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ad3qn","text":"Add correct volume of ethanol to SW2 (e.g. for 250 prep kit, add  of ethanol to  SW2 concentrate). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":65,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":80,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"400","guid":"4F54E6D5736111EAB7BE0242AC110004","id":"90610","label":"","unit":2}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"100","guid":"4F54E77A736111EAB7BE0242AC110004","id":"90611","label":"","unit":2}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f3m1f","text":"Phosphate buffer preparation:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8ojsr","text":"The phosphate buffer must be prepared the same day, before starting the extraction protocol. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1uuhj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"80rk0","text":"Calculate the quantity of phosphate buffer required for the extractions. Prepare a little more especially for the extraction control. You will add the same volume of phosphate buffer as 2 or 3 times the dry weight of sample depending on the quantity of sediment sampled and the water content. You will apply the same ratio for all samples of a same study. It is important to take care to not sample too much sediments to be able to add the phosphate buffer in the 50 ml falcon and avoid overflowing.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"94o62","text":"Add the right quantities of NaH2PO4 and NA2HPO4 in the DNA-free water (To prepare   of phosphate buffer: add   of NaH2PO4 powder and  of NA2HPO4 powder) ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":81,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":109,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":133,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"is73","text":"Mix until the total dissolution of the phosphate powder. Please be sure that the phosphate powder is completely dissoluted (i.e. no powder emains in the bottle)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fkui4","text":"If you have, put in the UV box for    ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":35,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"dl8tk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"1","guid":"A15B22A0734A11EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"90612","label":"","unit":3}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"1970","guid":"A10E9E60734C11EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"90613","label":"","unit":5}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"14700","guid":"A83BC6E0734C11EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"90614","label":"","unit":5}},"3":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":900,"guid":"CB62D440734911EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"80977","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cdgf3","text":"Addition of phosphate buffer to samples:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ek895","text":"Add the same volume of phosphate buffer to each 50 ml falcon. Each falcon should receive 2 or 3 times the dry weight of sediment (e.g.  for   of dry sediment).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":134,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":140,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"ctvra","text":"Mix with an orbital shaker  ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":26,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"c7g9n","text":"During the shaking time, label the final collection tubes, Amicons and green columns and prepare the tubes for SB ( )","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":115,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"15","guid":"56449210734A11EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"90615","label":"","unit":2}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"5","guid":"6131A8C0734A11EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"90616","label":"","unit":6}},"2":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":900,"guid":"4E956850734A11EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"80978","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"3":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"200","guid":"E5475EF0734C11EA84E4C96E9A0B1769","id":"90617","label":"","unit":1}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bn5e3","text":"Centrifugations:  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":16,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"4kv0q","text":"Centrifuge the  falcons to separate the sediment  .","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":15,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":49,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"6eu2","text":"Transfer  of the supernatant to the amicons and centrifuge for   intervals until concentrated down to about   in filter (the time for concentration depends on the sediment type). You can decide to centrifuge nearly all the supernatant (e.g.   ) or only a part. If the concentration is fast we suggest to centrifuge all the supernatant. On an aluminium foil (avoid notebooks in a clean lab) note the quantity of supernatant added and the quantity obtained after the centrifuge to know the concentration rate (it is generally difficult to obtain exactly the 400 µl required for the following steps.
